summary: A letter from attorney Brad Edwards to the U.S. Attorney's Office in Miami, dated October 9, 2008, concerning the case Jane Doe # and Jane Doe #2 v. United States. The letter alleges the government submitted a sworn declaration containing false information about a provision in Jeffrey Epstein's plea agreement and requests a corrected filing. It also seeks clarification on whether victims were notified of a provision that was not actually part of the final agreement and mentions Epstein's attorneys' involvement.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing Jane Doe # and Jane Doe #2, alleging false statements in a government declaration and requesting corrections.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of a plea agreement; the letter discusses a provision in his plea agreement that the government now claims is not part of it.

connections.description: Edwards is an attorney for victims in a case against the U.S. related to Epstein's plea agreement, seeking to correct alleged false information about the agreement.

events.title: Submission of Sworn Declaration
events.description: A declaration was submitted to the court containing a potentially false statement about a provision in Jeffrey Epstein's plea agreement.

events.title: Victim Notification
events.description: Four victims, including Jane Doe # and Jane Doe #2, were contacted and provisions of an agreement were discussed, according to the declaration.

events.title: Government Filing on Victim Motion
events.description: The government filed "Respondent's Opposition to Victims' Motion to Unseal Non-Prosecution Agreement," which is referenced in the letter.

keyFacts: The government allegedly submitted a sworn declaration containing false information about a provision in Jeffrey Epstein's plea agreement.
The letter requests the government file a corrected declaration and explain how the false information was provided to the court and victims.
It questions whether victims were notified of a provision that was not actually part of the final plea agreement.
The letter references that Epstein and his attorneys approved the submission of false information to victims, according to a prior government filing.
Brad Edwards seeks to work out a joint stipulation of facts with the government or, failing that, to have the record corrected.
